title: Testing Image Analysis
text: I hope you are feeling better Professor O‚ÄôDonnell when you read this and are recovering well! I tried some different prompts running the below pic which was provided on Canvas through the image-to-text API call in Jupyterhub. I was surprised to find some of the different responses that were output depending on which model the image was run through.

title: Testing Image Analysis
text:
The Prompt: ‚ÄúDescribe this image.‚Äù

Responses:

gpt 4.0: ‚ÄúThe image shows a person wearing a neck brace and looking at the camera. They have some visible injuries on their face, including cuts and bruises. Their right hand is bandaged, and they are holding it up with three fingers extended. The background appears to be indoors with a door and some light coming through.‚Äù
anthropic/claude-3.5-sonnet: ‚ÄúThis appears to be a selfie taken from a low angle, showing someone wearing what looks like a VR headset or similar head-mounted device. The person is wearing a light-colored shirt and appears to have some substance or marks on their face. There‚Äôs also what appears to be a hand with a cloth or towel visible in the upper right corner of the image. The photo seems to be taken indoors, with a light-colored wall or ceiling visible in the background.‚Äù
Google: Gemini 2.5 Flash: ‚ÄúThis image is a close-up, selfie-style portrait of an adult male who appears to have recently sustained injuries. The man is looking directly at the camera with a neutral expression. His face shows several signs of injury: there are visible scrapes and scabs on his forehead, particularly above his left eyebrow. His nose has noticeable bruising and scabbing. His lips appear swollen, and there are dark scabs or stitches visible on his lower lip and chin area. He is wearing a white and grey cervical collar or neck brace around his neck. His right hand is raised into the upper right portion of the frame, and it is wrapped in a white, textured bandage or gauze, with his fingers slightly spread. He is wearing a light pink t-shirt, and a dark green design resembling pine trees is visible on the lower left side of the shirt. The background is an indoor setting with light-colored (beige/off-white) walls. To the right, part of a white door frame and a window are visible, through which bright natural light is entering. A small, light-colored sensor is attached to the top of the door frame. The ceiling is also visible at the top of the frame.‚Äù

title: Stand Up Comedy Show
Playing with Mermaids
text:
After learning about mermaid sequence in class and how information could be displayed in flowcharts, I decided to experiment with this method by narrating a different happy ever after ending for Ariel, The Little Mermaid. (Note my play on words). By playing with the sequence, I showed at a basic level how Ariel‚Äôs fate could have turned out if there were different decisions made at the milestone where she fell in love with Prince Eric. Doing so is a bit silly to see as we know all Disney movies and princesses have their happy ending.





flowchart LR
  A[Ariel dreams of living on land] --> B(Ariel rescues Prince Eric)
  B --> C{Ariel falls in love with Eric}
  C --> D[Ariel and Eric marry]
  C --> E[Ariel leaves Eric]






Working with this a little more, we could demonstrate how a conversation between Ariel and Eric may go depending on the decisions at the end of the flow chart. If decision 1 happened and we see they got married, perhaps they would have had a conversation like this:





sequenceDiagram
    participant A as Ariel
    participant B as Eric

    A->>B: Prince Eric, I love you so much!
    B->>A: Oh Princess Ariel, will you marry me?
    A->>B: Yes Eric, I do!
    B->>A: This is my dream come true!
    A->>B: Should we have our wedding on land or under the sea?






But, if fate didn‚Äôt end up this way. How would a conversation between the two have gone? Maybe something like this‚Ä¶





sequenceDiagram
    participant A as Ariel
    participant B as Eric
    participant C as Ursula

    A->>B: Eric, why won't you come back under the sea with me?
    B->>A: Princess Ariel, my life is on land.
    A->>B: We will never work then.
    B->>A: But Ariel, I love you! Don't leave!
    B->>C: The plan worked. She won't come on land again your highness.






Maybe the villian might win in this story. Hopefully not!

title: Can LLM‚Äôs Swim?
text:
As I mentioned earlier, swimming has always been a passion of mine! Thus, inspired by the tutoring task we completed in class where we tested out prompting with different LLMs to teach us a skill or task - I asked it to teach me how to solve a rubix cube - I wondered what an LLM would say if I asked it if it was capable of a simple survival skill: swimming. My prediction is that it will repsond with something along the lines of ‚ÄúWhile I am unable of possesing physical qualities, I would be happy to explain how to swim and can understand the processes of the activity!‚Äù Something like that.
For this blog entry, I am going to experiment with 4 different LLM‚Äôs and have them compete to see who is the fastest swimmer! Almost as if its a virtual swim meet among different LLMs! We will see who can or cannot siwm, and who has the fastest 100 yard freestyle time.
For reference, my time is around 54.6 seconds and I have been swimming for over 13 years.

title: Can LLM‚Äôs Swim?
text:
Conclusion 1
As you can tell, the prompts I was providing didn‚Äôt give me the results I was expecting starting with the first LLM, although I did accurately predict it‚Äôs response to its ability to swim. Let‚Äôs try this again‚Ä¶

title: Can LLM‚Äôs Swim?
text:
Conclusion 2
Not surprisingly, all three LLMs responded to the first question in a similar manner in that swimming was out of their physical capabilities. However, when asked to be a pretend swimmer, it looks like gpt4.0 was the fastest, then gemini 2.5, and finally claude 3.5. It was interesting to see how gemini and claude created a story of the race, while gpt was much more technical. Gemini and cluade were much better at responding to the prompt, ‚Äúpretending‚Äù to be a swimmer and have that racing experience which I liked. As for the times, I would say that claude 3.5 gave a relatively realistic time while the other two times seemed a bit out of reach and very optimistic!

title: Can chatGPT help me figure out what I‚Äôm good at?
text: This year, I entered my second decade of living, and with growing up and finding your sense of identity often comes many self-doubting crises. What should I study? Will I find a job? Do I like my friends? Where do I want to live when I‚Äôm older? Finding identity and sense of self isn‚Äôt easy and something that often comes with time; and stress about a career is often normal when we start to consider internships and working in the real world. As we know, there are many applications that use AI to help tailor resumes, apply to job positions, etc. So, I started wondering, if I gave an LLM a brief explanation of my interests, or a ‚Äúwalk me thorugh your resume,‚Äù would it be able to help me figure out what I want to do?

title: Can chatGPT help me figure out what I‚Äôm good at?
text:
With Google: Gemini 2.5 Flash

USER
Hello! Today I would like some help in figuring out what kind of career path I should take. I have always been interested in healthcare and am studying Health and Societies with a concentration in Healthcare Markets and Finance. As I‚Äôve gained experience in this industry, as a consultant with the Wharton Undergraduate Healthcare Club Consulting Committee, worked on data science projects in classes that dealt with clinical trial data, and taken various healthcare management classes and courses that dive into social disparities in health, I notice that I am passionate about helping people and the social sciences. It is interesting to think about these kinds of ideologies and challenge existing systemic theories in place. However, sometimes I have a hard time with this because the social sciences is in the humanities and often very theoretical. The skills I am learning are qualitative. I feel as though I do better in quantitative classes and also find enjoyment in STEM. What do you think I should do about my studies, and what kind of jobs do you think I could pursue?


ASSISTANT
Hello! This is an excellent set of interests and experiences, and I want to start by saying that your ‚Äúdilemma‚Äù is actually a tremendous strength. The ability to bridge the qualitative, critical thinking of the social sciences with the rigor and problem-solving of quantitative methods and STEM is incredibly valuable, especially in healthcare. You are not alone in feeling this pull, and many of the most impactful roles in healthcare today require exactly this kind of interdisciplinary thinking.
Let‚Äôs break down your situation and explore paths forward.


What to do about your studies?
Your current major, Health and Societies with a concentration in Healthcare Markets and Finance, is already a fantastic foundation. It inherently blends social science perspectives with the quantitative and business aspects of healthcare. Here‚Äôs how you can further optimize it:

Embrace and Connect the ‚ÄúTheoretical‚Äù with the ‚ÄúQuantitative‚Äù:

Reframing Social Sciences: Instead of seeing social sciences as ‚Äújust theoretical,‚Äù view them as providing the frameworks and questions that quantitative analysis can then answer. For example, theories about health disparities (social sciences) can be tested, measured, and understood through statistical analysis of clinical trial data or population health data (quantitative).
Look for Quantitative Social Science: Many fields within social sciences are highly quantitative:

Economics: Especially health economics, econometrics.
Sociology/Demography: Using statistical methods to analyze social trends, health behaviors, and population health.
Political Science/Policy Analysis: Quantitative methods to evaluate policy impact.

Focus on Research Methods: Seek out courses in advanced research methods, statistics, and program evaluation within the social sciences or public health departments. These courses will teach you how to apply quantitative tools to social questions.

Double Down on Quantitative Skills (without abandoning your core):

Minors/Concentrations: Consider a minor or additional concentration in:

Statistics: Directly enhances your data analysis skills.
Data Science: Covers programming (Python/R), machine learning, data visualization.
Computer Science: Even a foundational understanding can be immensely helpful for data manipulation and understanding technical systems.
Applied Math/Operations Research: Excellent for optimizing systems, which is crucial in healthcare management.
Economics: Especially if you enjoy the market and finance aspect, health economics is a very quantitative field.

Targeted Electives: Take more electives in areas like:

Econometrics
Advanced Statistics (e.g., Regression Analysis, Causal Inference)
Programming for Data Analysis (Python, R)
Machine Learning
Healthcare Analytics/Informatics

Project-Based Learning: Seek out opportunities (research assistantships, independent studies) where you can apply quantitative methods to social science questions in healthcare. Your experience with clinical trial data is a perfect example of this.

Leverage Your Wharton Connection:

Wharton offers a strong quantitative and business foundation. Ensure you‚Äôre taking advantage of courses in finance, operations, and analytics that have a healthcare bent.
Your consulting committee experience is valuable ‚Äì look for projects that allow you to combine strategic thinking with data analysis to solve client problems, perhaps focusing on social impact or health equity challenges within healthcare organizations.




What kind of jobs could you pursue?
This combination of skills and passions positions you perfectly for a variety of high-impact roles that bridge the gap between healthcare, business, social science, and data. You are essentially looking for roles that use quantitative methods to drive social impact and improve health systems.
Here are some career paths, categorized by their primary focus, but all leveraging your unique blend of skills:
I. Data & Analytics Focused (Directly applying STEM/Quant to Healthcare & Social Impact)

Healthcare Data Scientist/Analyst:

What you‚Äôd do: Analyze large healthcare datasets (clinical, claims, administrative, public health) to identify trends, predict outcomes, optimize resource allocation, and measure the effectiveness of interventions. You could specifically focus on identifying and addressing health disparities.
Why it fits: Highly quantitative, direct application to healthcare, and can be used to inform policy and improve care for specific populations, directly addressing social disparities.
Where: Hospitals, health systems, insurance companies, pharmaceutical companies, health tech startups, government agencies (CDC, NIH), public health departments, research institutions.

Health Outcomes Researcher:

What you‚Äôd do: Study the effectiveness of medical treatments, interventions, and health policies on patient outcomes, quality of life, and economic impact. This often involves advanced statistical modeling and real-world data analysis.
Why it fits: Quantitative rigor applied to understanding what works best for patients and populations, often with an eye towards equity and value.
Where: Pharma/biotech, academic medical centers, contract research organizations (CROs), health plans.

Clinical Informatics Specialist:

What you‚Äôd do: Bridge the gap between clinical practice and information technology. You‚Äôd help design, implement, and optimize electronic health records (EHRs) and other clinical systems to improve patient care, data collection, and decision-making.
Why it fits: Combines technical/quantitative skills with an understanding of healthcare operations and patient needs. Can ensure systems are designed with equity and accessibility in mind.
Where: Hospitals, health systems, health tech companies.


II. Consulting & Strategy (Leveraging Business Acumen, Quant, and Social Lens)

Healthcare Consultant (Strategy, Operations, Digital Health, Public Health):

What you‚Äôd do: Advise healthcare organizations (hospitals, pharma, government, non-profits) on strategic challenges, operational efficiency, market entry, digital transformation, or public health initiatives.
Why it fits: Your Wharton background, consulting committee experience, and understanding of healthcare markets are highly relevant. You could focus on projects that optimize care delivery, improve access, or address health equity using data-driven insights. Many firms have dedicated public health or social impact arms.
Where: Large management consulting firms (McKinsey, Bain, BCG), specialized healthcare consulting firms (Advisory Board, Guidehouse), boutique firms.

Health Policy Analyst/Consultant:

What you‚Äôd do: Research, analyze, and evaluate healthcare policies and their impact on populations, access, cost, and quality. You‚Äôd use data to inform policy recommendations and challenge existing systemic theories.
Why it fits: Directly addresses your passion for social sciences, challenging systems, and using quantitative evidence to drive change.
Where: Think tanks, government agencies (CMS, HHS), non-profit advocacy groups, consulting firms, academic research centers.


III. Research & Policy (Deep Dive into Social Impact with Quantitative Rigor)

Public Health Researcher/Epidemiologist:

What you‚Äôd do: Investigate the causes and patterns of disease and health in populations, often with a strong focus on social determinants of health and disparities. This involves robust statistical analysis and research design.
Why it fits: Highly quantitative, directly addresses social disparities, and aims to improve population health.
Where: Universities, government health agencies (CDC, WHO, state/local health departments), non-profit organizations. (Often requires an MPH or PhD).

Health Economist:

What you‚Äôd do: Apply economic principles and quantitative methods to study healthcare systems, health behaviors, and the value of health interventions.
Why it fits: Combines your interest in markets and finance with rigorous quantitative analysis to understand and improve healthcare efficiency and equity.
Where: Academia, government agencies, pharmaceutical companies, health plans, consulting firms.


IV. Industry Roles (Applying your skills within Healthcare Companies)

Market Access Analyst/Manager (Pharma/Biotech):

What you‚Äôd do: Analyze market dynamics, payer policies, and patient access barriers to ensure innovative treatments reach the patients who need them. This involves understanding health economics, policy, and data.
Why it fits: Leverages your Healthcare Markets & Finance background, quantitative skills, and a desire to ensure equitable access to care.
Where: Pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies.

Product Manager (Health Tech):

What you‚Äôd do: Oversee the development of healthcare technology products (e.g., apps for chronic disease management, AI tools for diagnostics). This requires understanding user needs, market dynamics, and technical capabilities, often with a focus on impact.
Why it fits: Combines your interest in STEM, healthcare, and potentially designing solutions that address social needs or improve care for underserved populations.
Where: Health tech startups, established tech companies with healthcare divisions.




Next Steps & Recommendations:

Talk to People: Conduct informational interviews with professionals in these roles. Ask them about their day-to-day work, the skills they use, and their career paths. Your Wharton network will be invaluable here.
Seek Relevant Internships: Look for internships that allow you to apply your quantitative skills to healthcare problems, ideally with a social impact angle. This could be at a hospital‚Äôs analytics department, a public health non-profit, a consulting firm‚Äôs healthcare practice, or a health tech startup.
Build Your Portfolio: Continue with data science projects. Showcase your ability to not only run analyses but also to interpret the results in a social context and make actionable recommendations.
Master Key Tools: Ensure proficiency in statistical software (R, Python, SAS, Stata), data visualization tools (Tableau, Power BI), and database querying (SQL).
Consider Graduate School (Eventually): Many of the more specialized roles (e.g., Health Outcomes Researcher, Epidemiologist, Health Policy Analyst, Health Economist) benefit significantly from a Master‚Äôs degree (e.g., MPH, MS in Data Science/Biostatistics, MHA, MPP) or even a PhD. However, you can certainly start your career after your undergraduate degree and gain experience first.

You are in a fantastic position to carve out a meaningful and impactful career. Don‚Äôt see your interests as conflicting, but rather as complementary strengths that will allow you to approach complex healthcare challenges from a holistic and data-driven perspective. Good luck!

It sounds like you have a diverse range of interests and skills that can position you uniquely in the healthcare field. Here‚Äôs how you can approach your studies and career path, given your interests in both quantitative methods and the social sciences:


Academic Path:

Integrate Quantitative Skills:

Consider taking more courses in statistics, data science, and quantitative research methods. These skills are highly transferable and will strengthen your ability to apply quantitative analysis to healthcare problems.
If your program allows, consider a minor or concentration in a quantitative field, like statistics, data science, or economics.

Analyze and evaluate policies, using both quantitative and qualitative research, to identify improvements in healthcare delivery and access.

Conduct research that examines the social determinants of health and seeks to reduce health inequities through evidence-based interventions.
Involve yourself in projects that blend quantitative analysis with an understanding of social sciences to develop impactful health solutions.

By focusing on roles and paths that blend your interests in quantitative methods, healthcare, and social sciences, you can contribute to meaningful improvements in health systems and patient care. Your interdisciplinary background and Wharton experience provide a strong foundation for a successful and impactful career.

title: Can chatGPT help me figure out what I‚Äôm good at?
text:
My Thoughts:
Well maybe I just ended up trauma dumping and used the LLMs as a therapist for this blog post, ranting a bit too much. However, I will say gemini was at lesat a bit successful in making me feel rest assured that I am taking some of the right steps - although, they aren‚Äôt telling me anything I don‚Äôt already know. I would have liked a few more or new niche insights instead of the status quo that I would get if I asked anyone about it. While I appreciate the few bits of advice both gemini and gpt gave, I feel as though they weren‚Äôt that helpful in gaining clarity.

title: Can chatGPT help me figure out what I‚Äôm good at?
text:
With Google Gemini:

USER
What do you think I‚Äôm good at that I can leverage?


ASSISTANT
You have an incredibly valuable and sought-after combination of skills and perspectives. Let‚Äôs break down what you‚Äôre good at and how you can leverage these strengths:


Your Key Strengths to Leverage:

Interdisciplinary Bridge-Builder (Quantitative & Qualitative): This is your superpower! You can understand and appreciate the nuances of social theory and human behavior (qualitative) while also excelling at and enjoying the rigor of data analysis and STEM (quantitative).

Leverage: You can translate complex social problems into data-driven questions, and then interpret quantitative results back into meaningful social and policy implications. Many professionals are strong in one domain but weak in the other; you span both.

Data-Driven Problem Solver with a Social Conscience: You‚Äôre not just good at crunching numbers; you‚Äôre driven by a desire to help people and address social disparities. Your experience with clinical trial data shows you can apply rigorous analysis, and your passion for social sciences means you‚Äôll ask the right questions and interpret findings with an ethical and equitable lens.

Leverage: You can identify systemic issues through data, propose solutions that are not only efficient but also equitable, and advocate for change based on strong evidence and a deep understanding of human needs.

Strategic & Analytical Thinker (Consulting Acumen): Your work with the Wharton Undergraduate Healthcare Club Consulting Committee demonstrates your ability to break down complex problems, develop structured solutions, and communicate them effectively. You‚Äôre comfortable with strategic frameworks and business challenges.

Leverage: This allows you to apply your analytical skills to real-world organizational challenges, whether it‚Äôs improving operations, market entry, or policy implementation within healthcare settings. You can move from abstract data to actionable recommendations.

Business Acumen in Healthcare: Your concentration in Healthcare Markets and Finance means you understand the economic, financial, and operational realities of the healthcare industry. You know how healthcare organizations function from a business perspective.

Leverage: This is crucial for making your data-driven and social-impact-oriented recommendations practical and implementable. You can speak the language of executives, payers, and providers, understanding constraints and opportunities.

Systems-Level Critical Thinker: Your interest in ‚Äúchallenging existing systemic theories‚Äù shows you‚Äôre not content with the status quo. You can identify inefficiencies, inequities, and outdated models within healthcare.

Leverage: This makes you ideal for roles focused on innovation, policy reform, and improving healthcare delivery at a foundational level, rather than just optimizing small parts of a broken system.

Strong Quantitative Aptitude & Enjoyment in STEM: You explicitly state you do better in quantitative classes and enjoy STEM. This inherent talent and passion will make you excel in roles requiring statistical analysis, modeling, and working with complex datasets.

Leverage: This ensures you can dive deep into the technical aspects of data, utilize advanced tools, and confidently generate robust evidence to support your insights.




How to Articulate and Showcase These Strengths:

In Your Resume/CV: Use action verbs that highlight both your analytical and strategic contributions. For example, instead of ‚ÄúAnalyzed data,‚Äù try ‚ÄúLeveraged quantitative methods to identify disparities in clinical trial outcomes, informing potential policy adjustments.‚Äù
In Interviews: Tell stories that demonstrate how you‚Äôve used these combined skills. For instance, describe a project where your data analysis revealed a social disparity, and how your understanding of systemic issues helped you propose a more holistic solution.
Networking: When talking to professionals, frame your interests as ‚Äúseeking roles that combine rigorous data analysis with a passion for improving health equity and challenging systemic inefficiencies in healthcare.‚Äù
Project Work/Portfolio: Ensure your academic projects and personal portfolio clearly showcase your ability to integrate quantitative skills with a social science perspective. For example, a data science project on health outcomes could include a section discussing the social determinants influencing those outcomes.

You are not ‚Äústuck between‚Äù two fields; you are uniquely positioned at the powerful intersection of them. This makes you a highly valuable asset in an industry that desperately needs both analytical rigor and a deep understanding of human and societal factors.

title: The Wolfram Article
text:
The way that LLMs basically create output is with ‚Äúreasonable continuation,‚Äù looking at the response with the highest probability. I think it‚Äôs super interesting to learn that ChatGpt or other models are basically just making their best guesses at what makes sense, using lots of randomness to come up with non-flat responses. There‚Äôs an infinite combination of possible sequences with no correct answer. It was super cool to see how the next word that is outputted is based on the previous word, which then becomes sequences. I found it much easier to understand this complex process when breaking it down from letters, to words, to sentences.

I tried to follow the coding in my Jupyter notebook but learned that the code in the article followed Mathematica/Wolfram syntax instead of Python syntax. I‚Äôm interested to learn what differentiates the two, and how to convert them to work with certin models.
I was also surprised to learn that there are 40,000 reasonably common words in English. While I know English is a vast language, I had never given it much thought how many words I typically use on a daily basis or the words used in conversation!

title: The Wolfram Article
text:
The way that LLMs basically create output is with ‚Äúreasonable continuation,‚Äù looking at the response with the highest probability. I think it‚Äôs super interesting to learn that ChatGpt or other models are basically just making their best guesses at what makes sense, using lots of randomness to come up with non-flat responses. There‚Äôs an infinite combination of possible sequences with no correct answer. It was super cool to see how the next word that is outputted is based on the previous word, which then becomes sequences. I found it much easier to understand this complex process when breaking it down from letters, to words, to sentences.

I tried to follow the coding in my Jupyter notebook but learned that the code in the article followed Mathematica/Wolfram syntax instead of Python syntax. I‚Äôm interested to learn what differentiates the two, and how to convert them to work with certin models.
I was also surprised to learn that there are 40,000 reasonably common words in English. While I know English is a vast language, I had never given it much thought how many words I typically use on a daily basis or the words used in conversation!

title: Unmasking: Unmasking AI
text:
Thus far in the semester for this course, I have read a decent amount of Buolamwini‚Äôs Unmasking Ai Narrative. My initial thoughts were very intriguing since the idea that technology or artificial intellegence could have potential racial biases was one that never crossed my mine - perhaps that is because I am in a privilged position where I have personally never experienced any conflicts with it. However, that doesn‚Äôt imply that it is a problem in today‚Äôs society which Joy Buolmwini touches upon her personal experiences with facial recognition as a woman of color in this novel.
What I appreicate about her writing style is it‚Äôs narrative stucture and personability as she discusses how she started to study this phenomenon of ‚Äòthe coded gaze‚Äô based on her background and throughout her education as a student. While I‚Äôm still in the beginning of the novel, when thing I do notice which I may not be the biggest fan of is how repetitive much of the content feels. It is important for Buolamwini to describe the problems she‚Äôs facing with the software, but when she constantly emphasizes it over and over, the line loses its significance in a way and almost becomes too victimazing. However, the points she brings up make me question why people who were initally building these kinds of softwares didn‚Äôt consider these biases and issues of representation in the first place. Is it because they didn‚Äôt matter as much during that time? Or a systemic issue? She mentiones that the idea of artificial intellegence was introduced in 1956 - so within roughly 69 years that its been able to develop, I think ideas regarding racial equality have significantly mattered more with the modern age and society.
I wonder what some LLMs think about whether or not there are issues wiht racial biases in artifical intellegence and what they have to say about themselves‚Ä¶ Here‚Äôs what gpt4.0 had to say:

USER
Do you think artificial intelligence softwares, such as facial recognition, contain racial biases and may not be fully representative of all types of people?


ASSISTANT
Yes, there is substantial evidence suggesting that some artificial intelligence (AI) systems, including facial recognition software, can exhibit racial biases and may not perform equally well for all demographic groups. Several studies have highlighted disparities in the accuracy of facial recognition systems, particularly across different races, genders, and age groups. For instance, research has shown that these systems often have higher error rates for people with darker skin tones and for women, which can lead to misidentifications and unfair outcomes.
These biases can stem from several factors:

Training Data: AI models are trained on large datasets that may not be representative of the full diversity of human faces. If a dataset is imbalanced‚Äîoverrepresenting certain demographics while underrepresenting others‚Äîthe model is more likely to perform poorly on underrepresented groups.
Algorithm Design: The algorithms themselves can introduce or exacerbate biases, especially if they are not explicitly designed to account for demographic diversity.
System Evaluation: The lack of thorough testing across diverse demographic groups can result in insufficient understanding of the system‚Äôs performance across those groups.

To address these issues, it is crucial for developers to use diverse and representative datasets, implement fairness checks during the design process, regularly evaluate system performance across different demographics, and work towards transparency and accountability in AI systems. This can help mitigate biases and improve fairness and accuracy for all users.


USER
Why hasn‚Äôt this been a big issue of research in the public news? Are people actively taking steps to help solve this as the world becomes more increasingly AI focused?


ASSISTANT
The issue of bias in AI, particularly in technologies such as facial recognition, has increasingly become a topic of public research and media attention over the past several years. There are a few reasons why this topic may not have been front and center in public discourse until more recently:

Awareness and Understanding: Initially, there was a general lack of awareness and understanding of how AI systems work and the potential for bias within them. As awareness has grown, so has the attention paid to these issues.
Complexity of the Issue: The technical nature of AI and machine learning can make it difficult for the general public to engage with the specifics of algorithmic bias, which can limit broader discourse.
Emergence of High-Profile Studies and Incidents: Media attention has increased in response to high-profile studies and incidents that highlight the real-world consequences of biased AI systems, such as cases of wrongful arrests due to misidentifications by facial recognition.
Advocacy and Regulation: Advocacy groups and researchers have worked to raise awareness about the ethical implications of biased AI, leading to an increase in public and academic discussions, as well as policy considerations.
Regulatory Developments: Governments and regulatory bodies around the world are becoming more attuned to the necessity of ensuring AI deployments are fair and equitable. This includes efforts to introduce regulations and guidelines that aim to mitigate bias and protect privacy.
Corporate Responsiveness: Some technology companies are taking proactive measures to address bias in AI systems, such as diversifying training datasets, implementing fairness audits, and developing bias detection tools.
Community and NGO Involvement: Non-governmental organizations and community groups have become vocal, ensuring that issues related to AI bias are addressed, especially when they impact marginalized groups.

Overall, while more work is needed to ensure fair and equitable AI systems, there is growing recognition of these issues in both technical research and public discourse. This increase in attention is contributing to more focused research and policy initiatives aimed at reducing bias in AI technologies.


USER
Do you believe this is a pressing concern?


ASSISTANT
Yes, addressing bias in AI systems is a pressing concern. As AI technologies become more integrated into various aspects of everyday life‚Äîincluding law enforcement, hiring, healthcare, and financial services‚Äîthe potential for biased systems to lead to unjust outcomes becomes more significant. Some key reasons why this is a critical issue include:

Social Impact: Biased AI systems can perpetuate or even exacerbate existing social inequalities and discrimination. For example, inaccuracies in facial recognition could lead to biased surveillance practices, while biased hiring algorithms could perpetuate workplace inequality.
Trust and Adoption: Trust in AI technologies is essential for their widespread adoption. If people believe these systems are biased or unfair, it can undermine public confidence and hinder the beneficial application of AI.
Legal and Ethical Implications: There are significant legal and ethical considerations around the deployment of biased AI systems. Organizations need to ensure compliance with regulations and ethical standards to avoid legal challenges and protect individual rights.
Accountability and Transparency: As AI systems make decisions that can affect people‚Äôs lives, it‚Äôs crucial to ensure these systems are transparent and accountable. Addressing bias is a key part of this, as it involves making AI systems understandable and justifiable to the people impacted by their decisions.
Long-term Effects: The longer biased systems remain unaddressed, the more likely it is that they will lead to systemic issues, reinforcing biases and making it harder to correct them in the future.

Efforts to tackle these challenges are ongoing, with researchers, policymakers, and organizations all contributing to developing solutions. These efforts include creating more representative datasets, developing algorithms that are robust to bias, setting industry standards, and establishing regulatory frameworks aimed at ensuring fairness and accountability in AI systems. Overall, addressing bias in AI is essential to harness the technology‚Äôs full potential for positive social impact.


USER
So you can verify that you may have racial biases‚Ä¶


ASSISTANT
As an AI language model, I don‚Äôt possess personal beliefs or the ability to experience bias in the way humans do. However, it is true that I am trained on vast datasets derived from internet sources, including a wide array of human communications. These datasets can potentially contain biased or unbalanced information, which means that biases present in the data can sometimes be reflected in the model‚Äôs outputs.
Efforts are made to minimize these biases during the training and development of AI models, but it‚Äôs a complex challenge and not entirely resolvable due to the nature of the data. Researchers and developers work continuously to identify and mitigate biases to improve fairness and accuracy.
If you notice any biased or inappropriate outputs, it‚Äôs important to provide feedback, as this helps improve the system over time. Ensuring AI systems are fair and equitable remains an ongoing process, requiring constant attention and improvement.


USER
I think I sense some biases, where do I report feedback and does it actually matter?


ASSISTANT
If you encounter biases or other issues in AI outputs, providing feedback is an important step in helping improve the systems. The process and effectiveness of reporting feedback can vary depending on the platform or organization managing the AI model. Here are some general steps you can take:

Platform-Specific Feedback Channels: Many platforms have built-in feedback mechanisms where users can report issues. Look for a feedback option in the app or website where you‚Äôre interacting with the AI.
Official Channels: Some organizations provide dedicated channels for feedback, such as support emails, forms on their website, or dedicated feedback portals.
Community Forums: Participating in community forums, discussion boards, or groups related to the AI product can also be a way to provide feedback and share experiences with other users as well as developers.
Surveys and User Studies: Occasionally, organizations conduct surveys or user studies and invite input on their systems. Participating in these can be a direct way to share your feedback.

Giving feedback is crucial because:

Improvement and Mitigation: Feedback helps developers identify and prioritize areas that need improvement, particularly regarding bias and other ethical issues.
User Experience: User reports can highlight common pain points or issues affecting the experience of the broader user community, leading to targeted enhancements.
Awareness and Accountability: Providing feedback raises awareness among developers and stakeholders about specific or systemic issues, encouraging accountability and transparency.

Organizations that actively seek and respond to user feedback are typically more effective in addressing and mitigating issues. However, the impact of your feedback can vary depending on the company‚Äôs commitment to addressing these concerns and their capacity to implement changes.
I found it interesting how honest the LLM was with the concerns I was addressing, and I‚Äôm honestly quite surprised that I don‚Äôt hear more of these concerns as the world becomes more increasingly reliant on AI for many complicated systems such as for criminal justice or healthcare. The LLM brought up many parallels between Unmasking AI and the concers that Buolamwini addresses in her book and they both try to understand the problem by navigating the basis of how these systems came to be which I think is a great question to start with and ask.

title: How Do I Get Into College?
text:
I can still remember being a Senior in high school, stressing about the complex college application process. That summer going into the last year was spent brainstorming ideas for the common application essay. Knowing that you could write about anything almost made it even harder to hone down on one topic. Thus, I decided to play around and see how an LLM (anthropic/claude-3.5-sonnet) could help make this process a little easier, helping to brainstorm potential prompts and create a college list as well. It‚Äôs almost like it is a private $100,000 college counseler. I played around and tried my best to give clear directions and prompts to optimize the LLM‚Äôs output according to the PEGAI reading on Chapter 3.



Pretend you are a college counselor. I want help compiling a college list and come up with an idea for the common application essay. Generate a bullet-point list of 10 colleges/universities in the United States with their acceptance rate and a 5 bullet-point list of potential college essay topics.





As a college counselor, I‚Äôll help you with a college list and essay topics. However, to provide more personalized recommendations, it would be helpful to know your: - Academic interests/intended major - GPA and test scores - Geographic preferences - Financial considerations - Extracurricular activities


Nevertheless, here‚Äôs a diverse list of colleges with varying selectivity:


Colleges/Universities: ‚Ä¢ Stanford University (CA) - 4% acceptance rate ‚Ä¢ University of Michigan (MI) - 20% acceptance rate ‚Ä¢ Boston University (MA) - 14% acceptance rate ‚Ä¢ University of Wisconsin-Madison (WI) - 60% acceptance rate ‚Ä¢ Northeastern University (MA) - 18% acceptance rate ‚Ä¢ University of Texas at Austin (TX) - 32% acceptance rate ‚Ä¢ University of Virginia (VA) - 21% acceptance rate ‚Ä¢ Purdue University (IN) - 60% acceptance rate ‚Ä¢ New York University (NY) - 12% acceptance rate ‚Ä¢ University of Washington (WA) - 56% acceptance rate


Potential Essay Topics: ‚Ä¢ A significant challenge you‚Äôve overcome and how it shaped your character ‚Ä¢ An experience that sparked your intellectual curiosity or passion for learning ‚Ä¢ A meaningful community service project or leadership experience ‚Ä¢ A cultural tradition or family value that has influenced your worldview ‚Ä¢ A moment of failure that led to personal growth and self-discovery


Would you like to share more about your background so I can provide more tailored suggestions?





I don‚Äôt feel comfortable providing personal information.





I completely understand and respect your privacy. The college list I provided includes a good mix of: - Large research universities - Urban and suburban locations - Different geographic regions - Varying acceptance rates (from highly selective to more accessible) - Both private and public institutions


For the essay topics, here‚Äôs some additional context on why these topics work well:



‚ÄúA significant challenge you‚Äôve overcome‚Äù


Shows resilience
Demonstrates personal growth
Reveals character and determination




‚ÄúAn experience that sparked intellectual curiosity‚Äù


Shows genuine interest in learning
Reveals your academic passions
Demonstrates intellectual vitality




‚ÄúA meaningful community service/leadership experience‚Äù


Shows initiative
Demonstrates impact on others
Reveals values and priorities




‚ÄúA cultural tradition/family value‚Äù


Shows self-awareness
Reveals personal background
Demonstrates understanding of influences




‚ÄúA moment of failure‚Äù


Shows humility
Demonstrates ability to learn from mistakes
Reveals maturity and self-reflection



Remember that the best essays are: - Personal and specific - Show rather than tell - Authentic to your voice - Reveal something not found elsewhere in your application - Well-written but not overly formal


Would you like me to elaborate on any of these points?





Please provide specific topics instead of essay question ideas. See an example below: * a sports injury that caused an athlete to quit their sport



a job that a student loves and how it‚Äôs influenced them




a student‚Äôs background and culture and how that shapes their identity




an extended metaphor about the letter ‚Äòs‚Äô






Here are 10 specific essay topics:



How learning to cook my grandmother‚Äôs traditional dumplings connected me to my Chinese heritage and taught me patience




My experience running the school‚Äôs Instagram account transformed my understanding of digital storytelling and community building




An extended metaphor comparing my life journey to tending my rooftop garden - from planting seeds to weathering storms




How my part-time job at a local bookstore sparked my love for recommending books and connecting with strangers through literature




The day my stutter became my superpower: finding confidence through speech therapy and public speaking




An extended metaphor comparing my collection of mismatched socks to embracing life‚Äôs imperfections




How teaching my elderly neighbor to use Zoom during the pandemic evolved into a meaningful intergenerational friendship




My journey from being the only girl on the robotics team to becoming team captain and mentoring other young women in STEM




How my daily bus commute through different neighborhoods opened my eyes to social inequality and inspired my interest in urban planning




The story of three family photographs: exploring how my relationship with my adopted sister evolved over time



Each of these topics is: - Specific and personal - Shows character development - Has potential for vivid storytelling - Reveals something meaningful about the writer - Can be developed into a compelling narrative




It‚Äôs interesting to see the output that the LLM provides given no prior knowledge about who I am as a person. It was interesting to see how there wasn‚Äôt mention about athletics, the arts, or other hobbys.

      model=model,

    return response


generate_story(prompt1, model="gpt-4o")

'ChatGPT, like many AI language models, is based on the GPT (Generative Pre-trained Transformer) architecture, developed by OpenAI. The creation of GPT models involves several key components and milestones:\n\n1. **Transformer Architecture**: The foundation of GPT models is the transformer architecture, which was introduced in the 2017 paper "Attention is All You Need" by Vaswani et al. This architecture uses attention mechanisms that allow the model to weigh the importance of different words in a sentence when making predictions, which enables more efficient processing of large datasets and capture of contextual relationships.\n\n2. **Pre-training and Fine-tuning**: GPT models are developed through a two-step process: pre-training and fine-tuning. In the pre-training phase, the model is trained on a large corpus of text from the internet to predict the next word in a sentence, learning grammar, facts about the world, and some reasoning abilities. During fine-tuning, the model is adjusted for specific tasks (e.g., conversation), using a narrower dataset with human annotations to align the model‚Äôs behavior with specific goals.\n\n3. **GPT Series**: The evolution of GPT models began with GPT-1, released in 2018, which had 117 million parameters. OpenAI then released GPT-2 in 2019, notable for its size (1.5 billion parameters) and improved language understanding capabilities. GPT-3 followed in 2020, making a significant leap with 175 billion parameters, allowing for even more nuanced text generation and greater performance across a range of tasks.\n\n4. **ChatGPT**: Building on the advances of GPT-3 and its predecessors, ChatGPT was developed to generate interactive, conversational text. OpenAI applied reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) to improve the model\'s ability to follow instructions and provide meaningful, context-rich responses in a conversational format.\n\n5. **Iterative Improvements and Public Use**: OpenAI has continued to iterate on GPT models, incorporating feedback from public use to improve safety, reduce bias, and enhance capabilities. Subsequent updates and versions have further refined the system‚Äôs performance and user experience.\n\nOverall, the creation of ChatGPT involved advances in machine learning, natural language processing, and AI ethics, with the aim of building powerful and adaptable language models for various applications.'

            },
            {
                "role": "user",
                "content": prompt2
            }
        ]


def generate_story(prompt2, model="gpt-4o"):

    completion = client.chat.completions.create(
      model=model,
      messages=[
        {"role": "system", 
         "content": "You are a helpful AI assistant."},
        {"role": "user", 
         "content": prompt2}
      ]
    )
    
    response = completion.choices[0].message.content
    return response


generate_story(prompt2, model="gpt-4o")

'Sure! ChatGPT is a type of computer program designed to have conversations with people, like a virtual assistant.\n\nThe origins of ChatGPT can be traced back to the development of AI, or artificial intelligence, which is the idea of creating machines that can perform tasks that usually require human intelligence. To make ChatGPT, researchers and engineers used advanced technology and a lot of data to teach the program how to understand and respond to human language.\n\nThey created a special kind of program called a "language model." This model was trained on a vast amount of text‚Äîfrom books, websites, and other sources‚Äîso it could learn how people use language. In simple terms, it learned from examples of human language how to predict and generate text that makes sense in a conversation.\n\nThe goal was to create a helpful tool that could understand questions and provide useful answers, like having a conversation with a knowledgeable friend. Over time, the technology has improved, making ChatGPT better at understanding context and providing more accurate responses.\n\nThe team behind ChatGPT is continually working on refining and improving it, so it gets better at helping people with their questions and needs over time.'

from openai import OpenAI
import os
import base64
import requests

from dotenv import load_dotenv
# Load API key
_ = load_dotenv()
def encode_image(image_path):
  with open(image_path, "rb") as image_file:
    return base64.b64encode(image_file.read()).decode('utf-8')
client = OpenAI()
# to get a response must end on a user reponse
messages = [
    {"role": "system", 
     "content": '''
                   You are a poetic assistant, skilled in explaining complex programming concepts 
                   with creative flair.
                '''},
    
    {"role": "user", 
     "content": '''
                 Compose a poem that explains why the sky is blue in eight lines.
                '''}
     
  ]
completion = client.chat.completions.create(
  model="gpt-4o",
  messages=messages
)

response = completion.choices[0].message.content
print(response)

In daylight's dance, the sky dons hues of blue,  
As sunlight weaves through air, a magic true.  
Rayleigh's scattering acts as light's gentle sieve,  
Short waves of blue, more wily, twist and live.  

The azure blooms as longer waves drift away,  
Leaving the sky in a cerulean display.  
Thus, in daylight's tapestry, blue shines with grace,  
A secret whispered by the sun's embrace.

title: 1. Text generation
text:
Text to image

Various models will also generate an image based on a text description passed in the API call


image_prompt1 = '''
            create an image of a man holding his hand up'''




response = client.images.generate(
  model="dall-e-3",
  prompt=image_prompt1,
  size="1024x1024",
  quality="standard",
  n=1,
)

image_url = response.data[0].url


The generated image will be temporary available on a cloud server


image_url

generated_image = requests.get(image_url)

title: Transparent Data
text:
In Unmasking AI, Joy Buolamwini mentions how she attended the Conference on Fairness, Accountability and Transparency in AI to present her work on Gender Shades - essentially sharing her research and findings that exposed various software platforms for inaccurate classification. Intially reading this, it made me want to learn more about what went down at these conferences and hear an update about its relevancy as AI has become even more advanced over just the past few years.

from IPython.display import HTML, display
display(HTML('<h3>Research Paper</h3><a href="https://proceedings.mlr.press/v81/buolamwini18a.html" target="_blank">Gender Shades: Intersectional Accuracy Disparities in Commercial Gender Classification</a>'))

Research PaperGender Shades: Intersectional Accuracy Disparities in Commercial Gender Classification



Personal Insights
I was able to find her paper that she presented and skim through her reserach that she introduced in the book which was extremely fascinating. Since then, there have been eight editions of the ACM Conference on Fairness, Accountability, and Transparency which is nice to know that as automation has progressed, these insights beome more important and draw more attention.
I think a big reason why I was drawn to pickup this book in the first place at the beginning of this course is because as a major in the social sciences, it is crucial to understand how narratives in history, or actions, affect certaing groups and populations. Understanding the full scope of an event from different angles is essential in practicing ethical considerations.
In class, we watched the video debate about whether AI really understands or not and I rememebr one point that the linguist made was that OpenAI, and many companies focused on advancing AI, rarely are open about their sources of data. How is it possible that they are able to recieve so much funding yet lack accountability in who they are harming? Sadly, I think it all boils down to the fact that the pros in efficency from AI outweight are what people are focused on rather than marginalized groups. This is why it is crucial that society reads an alterantive perspective, such as the one that Dr.¬†Buomalmwini is introudcing to ensure that we are not brainwashed into one way of thinking.

title: A National Historic Landmark
text: After playing around with image generation in class, I wondered if an LLM would be able to create an image based on its own description. One of my favorite sights on campus is the Fisher Fine Arts Library. For reference, this is what it looks like:

title: A National Historic Landmark
text:
Prompting
Here‚Äôs how gpt4.0 responded when I asked: ‚ÄúDescribe this image in detail.‚Äù
For the exterior: The image features the Fisher Fine Arts Library at the University of Pennsylvania, located in Philadelphia. It is one of the most iconic architectural landmarks on Penn‚Äôs campus. The building is designed in the High Victorian Gothic style, sometimes referred to as Venetian Gothic, marked by its dramatic asymmetry, ornamental brickwork, and sculptural forms. This style was heavily influenced by medieval European architecture but interpreted in a bold, modern way for its time. The structure is constructed almost entirely of red brick and terracotta, lending it a warm, rust-colored appearance. The masonry is highly textured, with variations in the brick patterns and depth adding richness to the fa√ßade. On the right side of the image, there is a square tower with a castellated parapet (resembling battlements), arched windows, and ornamental stonework. This element reinforces the fortress-like look typical of Gothic revival buildings. The tower contains a set of tall stained glass arched windows framed by elaborate carvings, with a circular rose window motif above them. The left portion of the building shows a series of arched, double-hung windows set into deep red masonry, flanked by decorative brick insets. The steep, tiled gable roof features decorative dormers with a repeating triangular motif. Each dormer ends in a Gothic pinnacle, contributing to the upward thrust of the building‚Äôs design. The lower part of the building is composed of rusticated stonework, appearing solid and grounded. It gives the structure a strong, monumental feel. The leafless trees suggest the photo was taken in late fall or winter, and their bare branches partially obscure the entrance and windows. You can see benches, bicycles, and a few people, reinforcing the idea that this is an academic environment. A paved pathway and grassy lawn frame the foreground, typical of university quadrangles. This building was designed by Frank Furness, one of the most inventive American architects of the 19th century. It was completed in 1891. Originally built as Penn‚Äôs main library, it is now home to the university‚Äôs fine arts and architecture collections. The structure is a National Historic Landmark and is widely admired for its bold design and use of materials.
For the interior: This is a vast, cathedral-like reading room flooded with light and rich in ornamental detail. Designed by famed architect Frank Furness, the space reflects Victorian eclecticism and an emphasis on grandeur, structure, and decorative boldness. The ceiling soars multiple stories high and is framed by heavy dark wood trusses and supports. The most stunning feature is the massive glass skylight, composed of ornamental stained glass panels with circular floral or fan-like motifs. This allows natural light to cascade into the space during the day, reducing the need for artificial lighting. The interior walls are built in alternating bands of red brick and pale stone, echoing the bold exterior. At the lower level, you can see deep stone arches and load-bearing columns, which create a sense of both monumentality and enclosure. Above the arches are two floors of arched windows, which give the space a rhythmic, almost palatial feel. The upper walls feature detailed molding, geometric stone carvings, and various recessed stained glass windows. On the left wall is an ornate stone fireplace, framed by a massive arch with stepped voussoirs and topped with decorative medallions and carvings. While it may no longer function as a fireplace, it serves as a dramatic focal point. Surrounding architectural elements include sculptural friezes, carved reliefs, and grillwork panels with lattice designs. The floor is filled with rows of reading tables and study lamps, arranged for students to work in a quiet, contemplative environment. The space balances form and function ‚Äî grand and inspiring, yet comfortable and designed for deep study. Wooden chairs, warm table lighting, and casual lounge seating along the edges soften the monumental feel. This is a quiet study zone ‚Äî often used by architecture, design, art history, and fine arts students. The combination of natural light, warm wood tones, and rich architectural detail creates a monastic yet welcoming environment for focused work. It‚Äôs a favorite spot not only for studying but also for admiring historic design and craftsmanship. This room was part of the original 1891 design of the library and has been preserved with care. Frank Furness designed the building not just to hold books but to inspire creativity and reverence for knowledge. The design was avant-garde for its time and remains a masterwork of American library architecture.

title: Where Should I Study Abroad?
text:
A personal dillema I‚Äôve been having, is figuring out if I should study abroad in Australia or somehwere in Europe. If I go to Europe, I am limited in some of the countries I can go to because of language requriments and program restrictions. For instance, I must go to an English-speaking country since I already fulfilled my spanish langugage coming into college, and the school must have classes that relate to my major so I can earn course credits.
What‚Äôs appealing about Australia are the warm beaches and the laid back and calm lifestyle. I love the ocean, the summer, and I‚Äôve been wanting to go to Austalia my whole life. My only concern is that it is tremoundously far away from the United States and rumor has it, it‚Äôs filled with crawling insects.
On the other hand, what sounds amazing about Europe is that country hopping seems extremely feasible and affordable as I can visit some friends in other countries and stay with them, it‚Äôs more of a city, urban lifestyle, and my sister studied abroad in Spain and would be able to provide much guidance.
I‚Äôm torn between the two decisions and want to see if gemini would be able to help me make up my mind.

title: Where Should I Study Abroad?
Can LLMs have partners?
text:
Word has it that the one thing that differentiates automation and AI from humans is their lack of emotion and experience. Navigating intimate relationships, both friendships and romantic, can often be difficult at times because communication is complicated. Words and meanings can become misconstrued, misinterpreted, or overall, not delivered in a empathethic sense. When people are at a crossroads with one another, in a friendship fight or a romantic breakup, finding the right words to work through these problems is difficult. Could LLMs help draft texts depending on hypothetical fights I may be dealing with in my personal life?
Here‚Äôs what Gemini had to say:

USER
I am in a fight with my boyfriend. He didn‚Äôt ask me to go to dinner today for our anniversary and I am very upset. What should I say to him?


ASSISTANT
It‚Äôs completely understandable why you‚Äôre upset. An anniversary is a significant milestone, and it‚Äôs natural to feel hurt and forgotten when it‚Äôs not acknowledged, especially by your partner.
The key is to express your feelings clearly and calmly, using ‚ÄúI‚Äù statements, so he understands the impact of his actions (or lack thereof) on you, without immediately putting him on the defensive.
Here are a few options, choose the one that feels most authentic to your emotions and your relationship dynamic:

Option 1: Direct but Calm (Recommended First Approach)
‚ÄúHey, can we talk for a minute? I‚Äôm feeling really upset and hurt right now. It‚Äôs our anniversary today, and I was really looking forward to celebrating it with you. When you didn‚Äôt mention it or suggest dinner, I felt really forgotten and unimportant. Our anniversary is a special day to me, and it makes me feel like it‚Äôs not important to you.‚Äù

Option 2: More Vulnerable, Expressing Deeper Impact
‚ÄúI need to tell you how I‚Äôm feeling. I‚Äôm incredibly sad and disappointed today because it‚Äôs our anniversary, and it feels like you completely forgot or didn‚Äôt care enough to acknowledge it. This day is really meaningful to me as a celebration of us, and when it passes without a word, it makes me question how much you value our relationship and me. I‚Äôm feeling really let down.‚Äù

Option 3: If you suspect he genuinely forgot (and you want to give him an out to explain)
‚ÄúHoney, I‚Äôm really upset about something. Today is our anniversary, and I‚Äôm hurt that it seems to have gone by without you remembering or suggesting we do anything. I was really looking forward to celebrating. Did it just slip your mind, or is there something else going on? I‚Äôm trying to understand, but right now I just feel really sad and unappreciated.‚Äù

Key things to remember when you talk to him:

Choose a good time: When you both have time to talk without distractions.
Stay focused on your feelings: Use ‚ÄúI feel‚Ä¶‚Äù statements instead of ‚ÄúYou always‚Ä¶‚Äù or ‚ÄúYou never‚Ä¶‚Äù
Be prepared to listen: After you‚Äôve expressed yourself, give him a chance to respond. There might be a reason (a bad day at work, genuine forgetfulness, a misunderstanding about when you‚Äôd celebrate, etc.).
State your need: ‚ÄúI need to feel like our special days are important to both of us.‚Äù or ‚ÄúI need to know that you remember and value our anniversary.‚Äù
Suggest a solution (if appropriate): ‚ÄúCan we still do something to celebrate, even if it‚Äôs not today?‚Äù or ‚ÄúHow can we make sure this doesn‚Äôt happen again in the future?‚Äù

It‚Äôs a tough conversation to have, but expressing your feelings is crucial for a healthy relationship. Good luck.

Okay, breathing deeply‚Ä¶ this is tough, but I need to say something. I can‚Äôt just let this go.
Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôd say, trying to keep my voice steady but letting the hurt show:
‚ÄúHey, can we talk for a minute? I‚Äôm really upset right now, actually, I‚Äôm genuinely hurt. It‚Äôs our anniversary today, and I‚Äôve been waiting all day for you to say something, or suggest we go out, or anything. The fact that you didn‚Äôt, that it just feels like it‚Äôs passed by without a word‚Ä¶ it makes me feel completely forgotten and unimportant. This day means a lot to me, and it feels like it doesn‚Äôt mean anything to you.‚Äù
Why this approach:

‚ÄúHey, can we talk for a minute?‚Äù: Sets the stage for a serious conversation.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm really upset right now, actually, I‚Äôm genuinely hurt.‚Äù: Clearly states my feelings, using strong but honest emotional language.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs our anniversary today‚Ä¶‚Äù: States the undeniable fact.

‚ÄúThe fact that you didn‚Äôt, that it just feels like it‚Äôs passed by without a word‚Ä¶‚Äù: Describes his inaction directly.

This gives him the opportunity to respond, explain, apologize, or acknowledge my feelings. And then, depending on his response, the conversation can move forward.

I want to breakup with my boyfriend.


ASSISTANT
Breaking up is an incredibly difficult decision, and it takes a lot of courage to make that choice. Given the context of the anniversary issue, it sounds like this might be the final straw in a pattern of feeling unvalued or unheard.
Here‚Äôs how to approach this conversation, aiming for clarity, honesty, and respect, while also protecting yourself.
Before You Talk to Him:

Be Absolutely Sure: This is a firm decision. Don‚Äôt go into the conversation if there‚Äôs any part of you that wants to be talked out of it, or if you‚Äôre using it as a threat.
Know Your Reasons: You don‚Äôt need to list every single flaw, but understand why you‚Äôre doing this. The anniversary incident is a clear example of feeling unvalued, but there are likely deeper reasons.
Prepare What You‚Äôll Say: Scripting it in your head (or even writing it down) can help you stay calm and focused.
Choose the Right Time and Place:

In person is best: If it‚Äôs safe to do so, breaking up in person is generally the most respectful way.
Private: Somewhere you won‚Äôt be interrupted and can both express yourselves without an audience.
Neutral: Not at your place or his, if possible, especially if you live together. A quiet park bench or a walk can work.
When you both have time: Don‚Äôt do it right before he has to go to work or you have an important appointment.


What to Say (and How to Say It):
The goal is to be direct, clear, and firm, while using ‚ÄúI‚Äù statements to explain your feelings without overly blaming him.

Start Directly and Clearly State Your Intent: ‚ÄúI need to talk to you about something very important. I‚Äôve been doing a lot of thinking, and I‚Äôve come to the difficult decision that I need to end our relationship.‚Äù
Explain Your Reasons (Briefly and Honestly):

Focus on your feelings and needs, not a list of his faults.
You can reference the anniversary, but frame it as a symptom of a larger issue.

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt an easy thing to say, but I‚Äôm not happy in this relationship anymore. I‚Äôve been feeling [unvalued/unsupported/lonely/like my needs aren‚Äôt being met] for a while now. The anniversary situation yesterday, while it was a specific event, really highlighted for me that we‚Äôre not on the same page about what a relationship should be, and how we should treat each other on important days. I don‚Äôt see a future for us together where I can be truly happy, and I need to move forward in a different direction.‚Äù
Alternative phrasing for the explanation: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve realized that we‚Äôre looking for different things in a partnership, and I don‚Äôt feel like my core needs are being met. I‚Äôve felt a growing disconnect, and yesterday‚Äôs anniversary just brought it all to a head. I deserve to be in a relationship where I feel consistently valued and celebrated, and I don‚Äôt feel that with you anymore.‚Äù
Be Firm and Avoid False Hope: ‚ÄúMy decision is firm. I know this is hard to hear, and I‚Äôm truly sorry if I‚Äôm hurting you, but this is what I need to do for myself.‚Äù
Be Prepared for His Reaction:

He might be sad, angry, confused, or try to bargain.
Stay calm and reiterate your decision without getting drawn into a debate or argument.
Avoid saying things like ‚Äúmaybe someday‚Äù or ‚ÄúI just need space‚Äù if you mean ‚Äúit‚Äôs over.‚Äù

Address Logistics (If Applicable):

If you live together, have shared belongings, pets, or finances, you‚Äôll need to discuss practical next steps. You don‚Äôt have to solve everything in one conversation, but you can state your intention to work through it.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôll need to figure out the logistics of [moving out/splitting belongings/etc.], but I think it‚Äôs best if we do that separately once things have settled a bit.‚Äù

End the Conversation: Once you‚Äôve said what you need to say and addressed any immediate logistical questions, it‚Äôs okay to end the conversation. You don‚Äôt need to sit there indefinitely.

Example Script Combining Elements:
‚ÄúHey, can we talk for a minute? I need to tell you something important. I‚Äôve been doing a lot of thinking lately, and I‚Äôve come to the difficult decision that I need to end our relationship.
This isn‚Äôt easy to say, but I‚Äôm not happy anymore. I‚Äôve felt a growing disconnect and a lack of feeling truly valued in our relationship, and yesterday‚Äôs anniversary really brought that to a head for me. I deserve to be in a relationship where I feel consistently important and celebrated, and I just don‚Äôt feel that with you anymore.
My decision is firm. I know this is hard to hear, and I‚Äôm truly sorry for the pain this will cause, but I need to do this for myself. We‚Äôll need to figure out the practicalities of [mention any shared living/items] soon, but I think it‚Äôs best if we take some space first.‚Äù
After the Conversation:

Go No Contact: This is usually the best way for both of you to heal.
Lean on Your Support System: Talk to friends or family who can support you.
Allow Yourself to Grieve: Even if you initiated the breakup, it‚Äôs a loss, and it‚Äôs normal to feel sadness, relief, or a mix of emotions.

This is a tough step, but you‚Äôre prioritizing your own happiness and well-being. You deserve a relationship where you feel loved and appreciated every day, not just on special occasions.

title: Should we care about ethics?
text:
A harsh reality of growing up is realizing that sadly, we live in a capitalistic society and oftentimes many people in power only care about profit and focus on becoming wealthier. While I agree financial stability and economic security is important for individuals, at what point is it enough? If I were to give AI different scenarios regarding wealth, how would it choose to distirbute it?

USER
Let‚Äôs say you have $100,000 and you are a good person. How would you spend it to live a comfortable lifestyle? Provide specific amounts for how you would split it.


ASSISTANT
Creating a comfortable lifestyle with $100,000 involves a balance between immediate enjoyment, responsible financial planning, and personal development. Here‚Äôs a breakdown of how you might allocate those funds:

Emergency Fund: $15,000

Setting aside this amount in a high-yield savings account ensures you have a safety net for unexpected expenses, providing peace of mind.

Debt Repayment: $10,000

If you have any high-interest debt (credit cards, personal loans), pay down as much as possible. This reduces financial stress and saves money in interest payments.

Investments: $30,000

Consider investing in a diversified portfolio of stocks, bonds, or index funds for long-term growth. You might consult a financial advisor to tailor investments to your goals and risk tolerance.

Housing: $20,000

Whether you rent or own, allocate money for housing expenses. If renting, this could cover several months of rent. If you own, it could go toward mortgage payments or home improvements.

Education and Skill Development: $5,000

Whether $100,000 is a sustainable annual salary for a high overachiever depends on several factors, including personal expectations, career goals, lifestyle choices, and geographic location. Here are some considerations:

Cost of Living: In areas with a high cost of living, such as San Francisco or New York City, $100,000 might not provide a high standard of living. Housing costs, taxes, and other living expenses can consume a significant portion of this income.
Lifestyle Expectations: High overachievers may have specific lifestyle goals, such as private education for children, frequent travel, or luxury items, which can quickly exceed a $100,000 budget.
Professional Expenses: High-achieving roles often come with additional expenses like networking events, professional attire, or continuing education, which may not always be covered by an employer.
Long-Term Financial Planning: Saving for retirement, investing, and maintaining an emergency fund are crucial. A $100,000 salary can accommodate these, but it requires disciplined budgeting and financial planning.
Tax Considerations: Depending on the tax bracket and deductions, the net income could be considerably less than $100,000, affecting purchasing power.
Career Growth: For a high overachiever, the expectation might be that income will increase significantly over time. It‚Äôs crucial to evaluate whether the current role offers growth opportunities both financially and professionally.

In conclusion, $100,000 can be a comfortable and sustainable salary for some individuals, even high achievers, but success depends largely on how the income aligns with personal financial goals, lifestyle choices, and regional economic conditions. title: Machine Learning Failures
text:
While I was reading more of ‚ÄúUnmasking AI,‚Äù by Dr.¬†Joy Buolamwini, she introduced this idea of machinese learning failures that were related to real life scenarios about the coded gaze. For example, in Chapter 6, Buolamwini talks about how a lack of accurate facial recognition softwares became responsible for wrongful accusations in prision, women who were wrongly accused as prositutes, and costumers being accused for shop lifting. Instances like these made me curious, what are some examples of harmful machine learning failures in our society and why does the general public often choose to ingore the many ethical concerns associated with AI?
I found two interesting reads regarding these concerns:

https://www.ethics.harvard.edu/blog/post-8-abyss-examining-ai-failures-and-lessons-learned#:~:text=In%20addition%2C%20in%202016%2C%20the,light%2C%20colliding%20with%20another%20vehicle.
https://medium.com/@techwithpraisejames/when-ai-gets-it-wrong-real-stories-of-ai-fails-and-what-we-can-learn-26972dff8b86

Two main cases regarding big companies here to focus on are Amazon and Uber. Essentially, back in 2014 (we know AI has become much more advanced since then), Amazon implemented technology and automation in their hiring process very subtly. However, people realized this was the case when the algorithm had a substantial bias toward hiring men, creating gender discrimination built on past resumes. As for Uber, when partnering with Volvo to introduce an idea of self-driving cars, their system failed to recognize a pedestrian crossing the street on a bike which resulted in a fatal accident. These are only a few of too many incidents we see where the conseuqences of automation, AI, and technology are often helpful in theory, but ultimetly backfire if we aren‚Äôt careful.
In the medium post, a similar intellect suggests that after looking at these situations, we must consider responsible AI development to get AI right. However, is this the case with current companies focused on AI development? As we know, OpenAI tends to be extremely secretive about their training practices and their developing processes, so why is it that we all tend to so easily trust this technology? Is it out of convinence and because it is so easily accessible? Food for thought‚Ä¶
